conclusion: To determine at which moment the two objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the given velocity-time graph, which represents the relationship between the velocities v_A(t) and v_B(t) of objects A and B at different times t.

The graph shows two curves, one for object A (A) and one for object B (B). The vertical axis represents velocity (v) and the horizontal axis represents time (t). At time t = 0, both objects start from the same location with the same initial velocity v_0.

premise: The relative speed between object A and object B at any time t is given by the absolute difference of their velocities, |v_A(t) - v_B(t)|.
conclusion: The distance between the two objects increases when their relative speed is positive, and decreases when their relative speed is negative.
According to the diagram, the red lines are tangent to the velocity curves at specific points.

premise: We need to identify these tangent points to understand when the relative speed changes direction (i.e., from increasing to decreasing or vice versa).
conclusion: The tangent lines intersect the velocity curves at times t_1, t_2, t_3, and t_4. These points are where the relative speed might change direction.
Between t = 0 and t_1, both objects are moving in the same direction with decreasing velocities.
At t = t_1, object B starts moving faster than object A.
Between t_1 and t_2, object B continues to move faster than object A.
At t = t_2, object A starts moving faster than object B.
Between t_2 and t_3, object A continues to move faster than object B.
At t = t_3, object B starts moving faster than object A again.
Between t_3 and t_4, object B continues to move faster than object A.

premise: The maximum distance between the two objects occurs when the relative speed is at its maximum.
conclusion: From the diagram, the relative speed is maximum at t = t_2.
